Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. is committed to the safety of its employees and neighbors and operates the facility as a responsible member of the community. Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. encourages personnel to continually identify methods and procedures to reduce the use and risks associated with hazardous chemicals. This process includes protecting the community, environment, and personnel by implementing technology and procedures designed to reduce the impact of any potential release of toxic chemicals. This commitment to safety is documented in the policy and compliance manuals for this facility, which are available to all

employees.



As part of Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.'s commitment to safe and environmentally friendly operations, monthly meetings are conducted with all employees as well as other more specific operational meetings concerning safety. Input and comments from plant personnel are also key aspects of Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.'s safety practices: By giving personnel the ability to make suggestions regarding safety and operational practices, the facility can operate efficiently and safely. Another key element in Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.'s safety practices consists of the regular internal and third party environmental and safety audits.



Regulated Substances



The Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. facility stores the following:

?    maximum 2,400 pounds of Arsine

?    maximum 25,000 pounds of Ammonia

?    maximum 2,750 pounds of Chlorine



These chemicals are regulated at the Program 3 level.



General Accidental Release Prevention Programs and Prevention Steps



As part of the implementation of the PSM/RMP, elements of the prevention programs have been developed to manage process safety issues associated with the facility. Each of the program elements have been developed according to OSHA and EPA regulations in order to ensure safe operating practices and conditions at the Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. facility.



Preventio

n 3 Elements:



Process Safety Information - information regarding the hazards each chemical, process descriptions, and equipment properties.



Process Hazards Analysis - a detailed review of the process and recommendations to improve the safety of the system.



Operating Procedures - procedures designed to comply with regulations and provide safe practices for the system.



Training - procedures and logs for personnel training on the covered processes.



Mechanical Integrity - manufacturer recommended maintenance procedures, schedules, and documentation.



Management of Change - documentation and tracking of changes that affect the process involving the regulated chemicals.



Pre-Startup Safety Review - prior to the startup of a new regulated process or major changes to the existing process, a review will be conducted as required by the PSM/RMP regulations.



Compliance Audits - documentation of tri-annual audits of the covered process.



Incident Investigation - documentation and investigation procedures for determining and mitigating releases.



Employee Participation - documentation and statement of Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.'s commitment to providing a safe and open work place.



Hot Work Permit - procedures for documenting and safely performing work on or near process equipment during normal operations.



Contractors - policy for contractors and outside vendors that work on or near the regulated process.



These elements are continually updated and reviewed through the Management System at Matheson Tri- Gas, Inc. The Management System includes planning, organizing, implementing, and controlling different aspects of the plan.



Five Year Accident History



EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



On-site deaths, injuries, or significant proper

ty damage (?68.42(a)); or Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Arsine and ammonia will not be brought on-site until July 2, 2014. Therefore, the facility does not have a five year accident history and there have been no releases of any of the regulated substances that meet the RMP definition of "accident" as described above.



Emergency Action Plan



Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. has implemented a corporate Emergency Action Plan, which includes emergency and evacuation procedures, safety and health considerations, and notification procedures.



Planned Changes



Changes determined by the Process Hazard Analysis and consideration made during the development of this plan will be conducted in a timely manner. The PSM/RMP will be updated at least every five years and is due to be updated on the five year anniversary of the PHA study (May 2019). The PSM/RMP will also be updated within six months in the event of a change which requires a new Process Hazard Analysis.
